title: Coding Style Guide
text: Use <- assignment, =. function call, specify arguments name. Never specify partial name never mix position complete name. required arguments first, followed optional arguments. ... argument either beginning end. Set default arguments inside function using NULL idiom, avoid dependence arguments. Always validate arguments function. Specify namespace used function, except base package. put one statement per line. use semicolon termination command.
code: # GOOD x <- 1  # BAD x = 1 1 -> 1 # GOOD mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)  # BAD mean(x, na = TRUE) # GOOD raise_to_power(x, power = 2.7)  # BAD raise_to_power(power = 2.7, x) # GOOD standardize(..., scale = TRUE, center = TRUE)  # BAD standardize(scale = TRUE, ..., center = TRUE) # GOOD ggplot2::ggplot() dplyr::select()  # BAD  ggplot() select() # GOOD x <- 1 x <- x + 1  # BAD  x <- 1; x <- x + 1

title: Coding Style Guide
text: general rule, abbreviations must avoided naming.

title: Coding Style Guide
text: File names must use .R extension. File names must meaningful. File names must contain / spaces. Instead, dash (-) underscore (_) must used. File names must use letters Basic Latin, Latin-1 Supplement, must lowercase. Use meaningful verbs file names. AllClasses.R stores S4 classes definitions. AllGenerics.R stores S4 generic functions. zzz.R contains .onLoad() friends. Use -methods suffix S4 class methods. file contains one function, name function name.
code: # GOOD plot.R  # BAD plot # GOOD plot.R  # BAD Untitled1.R # GOOD read_csv.R plot-methods.R  # BAD read csv.R # GOOD plot.R  # BAD Plot.R données.R # GOOD fit_model.R  # BAD addition.R

title: Coding Style Guide
text: Variables names must short possible. Variables names must meaningful nouns. Variable names must lowercase. Never separate words within name . (reserved S3 dispatch) use PascalCase (reserved S4 classes definitions). Instead, use underscore (_). use names existing function variables (especially, built-ones).
code: # GOOD std_dev <- 3  # BAD std.dev <- 3 StdDev <- 3 # GOOD std_dev <- 3  # BAD T <- 1 c <- 2 * 2 mean <- 10

title: Coding Style Guide
text: Function names must contain verb refers primary action function. Function names must snake_case. Use . dispatching S3 generic. object_verb() naming scheme prefered often possible. scheme easy read auto-complete. Avoid function name conflicts base packages popular ones.

title: Coding Style Guide
text: Class names must nouns PascalCase initial capital case letter first letter subsequent concatenated word capitalized.

title: Coding Style Guide
text: maximum length lines limited 80 characters.

title: Coding Style Guide
text: Put spaces around infix binary operators (=, +, *, ==, &&, <-, %*%, etc.). Put spaces around = function calls. place space subsetting ($ @), namespace manipulation (:: :::), sequence generation (:). Put space comma. Use space left parentheses, except function call. spacing around code parenthesis square brackets.
code: # GOOD  x == y z <- 2 + 1  # BAD x==y z<-2+1 # GOOD  mean(x = c(1, 2, 3), na.rm = TRUE)  # BAD mean(x=c(1, 2, NA), na.rm=TRUE) # GOOD car$cyl dplyr::select() 1:10  # BAD car $cyl dplyr:: select() 1: 10 # GOOD  mtcars[1, ] mean(x = c(1, NA, 2), na.rm = TRUE)  # BAD mtcars[1 ,] mean(x = c(1,NA,2),na.rm = TRUE) # GOOD  for (element in element_list) if (total == 5) sum(1:10)  # BAD for(element in element_list) if(total == 5) sum (1:10) # GOOD  if (is_true) message("Hello!") species["tiger", ]  # BAD if ( is_true ) message("Hello!") species[ "tiger" ,]

title: Coding Style Guide
text: opening curly brace never go line always followed new line. closing curly brace always go line, unless ’s followed else. Always indent code inside curly braces. Curly braces new lines can avoided, statement short.
code: # GOOD  if (is_true) {   # do something }  if (is_true) {   # do something } else {   # do something else }      # BAD if (is_true) {   # do something }      if (is_true) { # do something } else { # do something else } # GOOD  if (is_true) {   # do something } else {   # do something else }  # BAD if (is_true) {   # do something } else {   # do something else  } # GOOD  if (is_true) {   # do something   # and then something else }      # BAD if (is_true) { # do something # and then something else } # Good  if (is_true) return(value)

text: use tabs mixes tabs spaces indentation. Use two spaces indentation.

title: Coding Style Guide
text: function definition call excessive arguments must indented closing parenthesis located, two lines sufficient. Otherwise, argument can go separate line, starting new line opening parenthesis. condition statement expands several lines, condition must end logical operator, start . statement, contains operators, expands several lines, line end operator begin . grammar statement dplyr (%>%) ggplot2 (+) start new line.
code: # GOOD long_function_name <- function(arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4,                                 long_argument_name1 = TRUE)                                 plot(table(rpois(100, 5)), type = "h", col = "red", lwd = 10,       main = "rpois(100, lambda = 5)") # GOOD long_function_name <- function(long_argument_name1 = c("value1", "value2"),                                long_argument_name2 = TRUE,                                long_argument_name3 = NULL,                                long_argument_name4 = FALSE)  list(   mean = mean(x),   sd = sd(x),   var = var(x),   min = min(x),   max = max(x),   median = median(x) ) # GOOD if (some_very_long_name_1 == 1 &&     some_very_long_name_2 == 1 ||     some_very_long_name_3 %in% some_very_long_name_4)  # BAD if (some_very_long_name_1 == 1     && some_very_long_name_2 == 1     || some_very_long_name_3 %in% some_very_long_name_4) # GOOD  normal_pdf <- 1 / sqrt(2 * pi * d_sigma ^ 2) *   exp(-(x - d_mean) ^ 2 / 2 / s ^ 2)  # BAD normal_pdf <- 1 / sqrt(2 * pi * d_sigma ^ 2)   * exp(-(x - d_mean) ^ 2 / 2 / d_sigma ^ 2)
